channel.title: R Markdown on Carlos Valenzuela
channel.description: Recent content in R Markdown on Carlos Valenzuela

item.title: I'm Back!
item.author: jour4life@gmail.com (Carlos Valenzuela)
item.description: I’m back! It’s been nearly two years since my last post. There have been a lot of great changes in my life. As a result, I did not have much time to dedicate to this blog. Because I’m always busy, I believe that my R and Python coding skills have been lagging behind. I will restart my blog in the next few days and hope to start working on some fun projects during my leisure time.

item.title: Changes in Tenure among Single Family Housing Units in Bexar County, 2007-2016
item.author: jour4life@gmail.com (Carlos Valenzuela)
item.description: In a previous post, I found that renter occupied housing units in Bexar County (as well as the rest of Texas), increased 15% between 2007 and 2016. I mentioned it was possible that growth in housing units may have kept pace with that of households due to growth in apartment complexes. However, I wasnâ€™t really sure if this was the case. During the Great Recession, many households lost their homes due to default, be it from job loss or rising interests rates for those with adjustable rate mortgages (ARM).

item.title: Some Thanks and Other Thoughts
item.author: jour4life@gmail.com (Carlos Valenzuela)
item.description: I want to thank people in the R community for everything they do to, such as creating new packages and platforms for people to share their ideas to the world. I am really grateful to people like Yihui who created blogdown and bookdown. I can’t say enough of how blogdown has changed the way I document and communicate analyses with others…and with such ease! I started using blogdown a couple of weeks ago and I can’t believe how easy it has been using blogdown to install hugo, write a post, and publish all in one place.

item.title: Bexar County Changes in Household and Housing, 2007-2016
item.author: jour4life@gmail.com (Carlos Valenzuela)
item.description: In the previous post, I looked at changes in household income and housing values between 2007 and 2016. The reason for looking at these changes was due to a recent post provided by the US Census Bureau that stated San Antonio added the most residents between 2016 and 2017. San Antonio, as much of Texas, experienced increased net in-migration since the Great Recession (2008). As a result, I wondered how these changes in population could have affected housing values.

item.title: Bexar County Household Income and Housing Values, 2007-2016
item.author: jour4life@gmail.com (Carlos Valenzuela)
item.description: My hometown of San Antonio added the most residents than any other city in the country between 2016 and 2017 (link). Since 2007, the population in San Antonio and surrounding areas have grown rapidly. One of the questions I have is, how have recent changes impacted housing values in the area during this time? How has household income fared in comparison? These questions are important because rapid changes in population can put a strain on the housing supply, which can lead to drastic increasing housing values due to a limited housing supply.
